block.p: Clinton Presses Congress On China Trade Issue President Clinton and top aides, acknowledging that they lack the votes to pass a China trade measure, asserted that the issue was as much about global leadership and the fate of Chinese reformers as about American business interests.

Debate Over the Holocaust Many Israelis observed the Day of the Shoah to remember the victims of the Holocaust, but many others in strictly Orthodox neighborhoods ignored the occasion, reflecting a complex dispute over not only how the Holocaust should be remembered but about Holocaust history itself.

Warning on Germ Warfare The General Accounting Office says there is no guarantee that some of the money sought by the Clinton administration for Russian-American biological projects will not be used by the Russians to research or develop germ weapons.
Hostage Deaths Reported Two foreign hostages held by Muslim rebels in the southern Philippines died during a clash between the rebels and government troops, a rebel leader said.

Conditions for Tidal Waves Scientists said they had found cracks in the seabed off Virginia and North Carolina that could set off a tsunami that might send waves as high as 20 feet speeding toward the Middle Atlantic states.

Speech Draws Producers' Ire The producers of ''The Ride Down Mount Morgan'' have filed a union complaint of unprofessional conduct against their star, Patrick Stewart, citing a speech he made from the stage accusing them of failing to promote the play adequately.

China Buys Back 3 Treasures A state-owned corporation, which until last year was owned by the army and is best known for global weapons sales, paid $4 million for three Chinese relics at auctions in Hong Kong that Beijing had challenged.
Penelope Fitzgerald The author of the 1995 novel ''The Blue Flower,'' about the German poet Novalis and his hapless love for a 12-year-old girl, was 83.
Jonah Jones A jazz trumpeter who played with some of the great swing bands and sold a million copies of his versions of ''On the Street Where You Live'' and ''Baubles, Bangles and Beads,'' he was 91.

G.O.P. Plan to Alter Schedule of Primary Voting A high-level Republican committee proposed a new presidential nominating system intended to build suspense and interest from March through June, with smaller states voting first and larger states casting the decisive final votes. The Republican national chairman said he expected the party to adopt the plan.

Gore Anticrime Proposal Vice President Al Gore called for a broad array of anticrime measures, among them mandatory drug testing of all prisoners and parolees. His proposal would have the government spend $500 million a year to help states test, treat and counsel prisoners and parolees for drug use.

Bush Aides Fight Back Aides to Gov. George W. Bush disputed accusations by Vice President Al Gore that Mr. Bush's fiscal proposals were risky. They said economic growth in the last six months meant that there would be enough money to easily accommodate the governor's spending and tax cut proposals.

White House Yields Documents The White House turned over seven documents sought by the House Government Reform Committee, abandoning its intention to invoke executive privilege in a dispute over a Congressional request for some documents related to missing White House e-mail messages.

Clinton Inquiry Was Sought Senator Arlen Specter said the former head of the Justice Department's campaign finance unit had urged appointment of an independent counsel to investigate President Clinton and a top Loral aerospace executive. A separate Justice Department inquiry looked into whether the company broke the law by providing important technological help to China's rocket program.
New Policy on Altered Food The Clinton administration is expected to announce today a strengthening of its policy on regulating the safety of genetically engineered foods.

Medicare Proposals Opposed The Justice Department said Congressional proposals to create an independent agency to run Medicare or administer prescription drug benefits for the elderly were unwise and probably unconstitutional.

Publisher Is Replaced Hearst replaced Timothy White as publisher of The San Francisco Examiner, a day after he testified that he had offered Mayor Willie Brown favorable editorials in exchange for his support of Hearst's purchase of The San Francisco Chronicle.

Report on Bonfire Accident A commission investigating the collapse of a Texas A&M University bonfire tower concluded that students made fundamental mistakes in building the structure and that university officials failed to control the project properly. The accident killed 11 students and a former student.
Arkansas Executes Woman Christina Marie Riggs, 28, was put to death by lethal injection for killing her two children, ages 5 and 2.

Panel Clears Pataki in Trips Linked to Corporations The State Ethics Commission found that Governor Pataki and his aides did not violate the law in letting a nonprofit trade group largely financed by companies lobbying his office pay for trips to Hungary.
Mr. Pataki refused to rule out running for the Senate if Mayor Giuliani's health forced him out.
Deal on State's Borrowing Governor Pataki and legislative leaders announced an agreement to limit the state's much-maligned borrowing practices, clearing the way for final passage of the budget.

Democrats Regain Nassau Craig M. Johnson won a special election to fill the seat in the County Legislature that was held by his mother, Barbara, whose death in March cost the Democrats their first majority in 80 years.

A Suicidal Car Crash Michael Dombrowski and Jeffrey Barton, eighth graders in East Haddam, Conn., killed themselves in a car crash on Monday in what appeared to be a suicide pact linked to the death of the brother of one of the boys in a crash at the same spot six months ago, the police said.

Schools Company Gains Recruit The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, a former congressman from Queens considered a potential candidate for mayor, is expected to announce today that he will head the charter school division of Edison Schools, which manages public schools for profit.
Racing Honors Julie Krone The retired jockey, who rode to victory 3,545 times during 19 seasons, became the first woman to be elected to racing's Hall of Fame.

Marathoner Gains Citizenship Khalid Khannouchi, the Moroccan-born runner who holds the world marathon record, became a United States citizen, but it was unclear whether he would compete in the Olympics this summer. He will hold a news conference today.

ABC Returns to Cable Time Warner put ABC television programs back on its cable systems after agreeing to a truce in its dispute with ABC's parent, Walt Disney. The action came as the F.C.C. was set to order Time Warner to restore the ABC signal until after the ratings sweeps period ended, on May 24.
Unilever Seeks Bestfoods Unilever made an unsolicited $18.4 billion bid to acquire Bestfoods, which rejected the offer.

AT&T Stock Drops 14% AT&T's quarterly results met analysts' expectations, but the company's warning that earnings and revenue growth for the full year would be lower than anticipated sent shares tumbling $6.8125, to $41.9375.
The Nasdaq fell 4.4 percent, and the Dow and S.& P. 500 declined, too.

Band Enters Online Music Fight The heavy-metal band Metallica today will seek to prevent 335,000 fans from using Napster, a service for sharing music collections over the Internet. A lawyer for the band said users were making Metallica recordings available for others to copy.
Car Buyers Undeterred Every big domestic and foreign automaker said sales last month exceeded even last year's brisk pace, despite rising interest rates, stock volatility and higher gas prices.
Editorials: Revolt of the business class; a needless showdown over Vieques; fire standards for cigarettes; the changing face of terror. Columns: Paul Krugman, Maureen Dowd.
